stream_context.summary: The stream focused on implementing and refining a new 'egg coin' radar system for the 7th mission of each level. Kaze iterated on the UI design to make it intuitive but not distracting, debugged a lighting issue caused by an obscure engine feature, and discussed future plans for the game's economy and level progression.

development_findings.summary: The game's mission structure is being changed to include a seventh mission in each level dedicated to finding 'egg coins', replacing the traditional 100-coin star.
development_findings.quote: Instead of six stars. There's now seven stars in the act select and the last act is always called find the egg coins

development_findings.summary: The new egg coin radar is directly inspired by the treasure hunting mechanic in Sonic Adventure 1.
development_findings.quote: My guys pulling something it's Sonic Adventure 1 but yeah It is very similar to that

development_findings.summary: After considering various UI options for the radar, Kaze prototyped and settled on a system where the icon's transparency indicates proximity, becoming more solid as the player gets closer.
development_findings.quote: this is kind of nice honestly the closer you are to it the more solid it gets

development_findings.summary: Kaze solved a bug where dynamic lights weren't appearing by discovering an obscure, built-in feature of the original SM64 engine, highlighting the challenges of working with legacy code.
development_findings.quote: There's a functionality in the Mario 64 engine where if you set the beep harm free to 255 the object does not spawn This is so fucking wild

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejected using the Rumble Pak for feedback because it requires its own programming thread and he personally does not own one for testing.
Project status update: Course 1 is nearly finished, Courses 13 (Ice Castle) and 14 (Craft World) are mostly done, and Course 15 (Space Arcade) is in the early planning stages.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a pragmatic view on programming, believing the language is less important than the result, and that C is sufficient for their needs.
context_findings.quote: only bad programmers care about the programming language... c can already do everything we need

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy prioritizes avoiding player frustration, leading him to make features like the coin radar a default part of a mission rather than a purchasable item that could be missed.
context_findings.quote: Imagine you have not bought the radar and you're doing a mission 7 and the game doesn't give you any hint at All that's gonna suck That's gonna be a miserable experience people are gonna hate that and I want to avoid that experience happening to anyone

context_findings.summary: When asked about his personal history with coding, Kaze deflects, stating his focus is entirely on the game itself, not on his personal story.
context_findings.quote: i think about game not about me i want game

context_findings.quote: The coins are gonna be there to buy over what upgrades so like maybe there will be a guy that wants to build a bridge But he needs a donation of 500 coins to buy the materials. So you give them the money and then the overall changes You're actually gonna affect the world by giving people money That's gonna be so cool

context_findings.summary: When asked about a potential Nintendo strike, Kaze dismisses it, stating he is certain it was initiated by an imposter, not Nintendo itself.

key_stories.title: Redesigning a Mission to Avoid Player Frustration
key_stories.summary: Kaze initially planned a purchasable radar for the new egg coin missions. He quickly realized this could create a frustrating dead-end for players and redesigned it to be an automatic feature, demonstrating his principle of prioritizing player experience.
key_stories.challenge: A new 'egg coin' mission was designed, but Kaze realized that making the necessary radar a purchasable item could lead to a 'miserable experience' for players who didn't buy it, leaving them with no guidance.
key_stories.process: Kaze evaluated the potential player journey and identified a major point of frustration. He then redesigned the feature, removing the purchase requirement and integrating the radar directly into the mission's core mechanics.
key_stories.outcome: The radar is now a non-optional, automatic feature of the 7th mission. This design change prioritizes a positive player experience over a potential resource-management mechanic.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine you have not bought the radar and you're doing a mission 7 and the game doesn't give you any hint at All that's gonna suck That's gonna be a miserable experience people are gonna hate that and I want to avoid that experience happening to anyone

key_stories.title: Iterating on the Radar UI
key_stories.summary: The egg coin radar's initial UI was confusing. Through live brainstorming and rapid prototyping, Kaze pivoted from a color-based system to one based on transparency, finding it a more effective and less intrusive solution.
key_stories.challenge: The initial UI for the new egg coin radar, which used changing colors to indicate proximity, was potentially distracting and confusingly overlapped with the collectible coins' own colors.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed solutions on stream, rejecting ideas like a 3D arrow as too intrusive. He then prototyped a suggestion to use transparency, immediately testing it in-game to evaluate its effectiveness.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a new design where the radar icon's transparency changes with proximity. He found this solution to be more elegant, less distracting, and it solved the color confusion issue.
key_stories.key_quote: this is kind of nice honestly the closer you are to it the more solid it gets

key_stories.title: The Case of the Missing Lights
key_stories.summary: While debugging missing lights, Kaze discovered the problem was caused by an obscure, undocumented feature of the original Mario 64 engine. This moment highlights the unique challenges of ROM hacking and building upon legacy technology.
key_stories.challenge: Dynamic lights that were placed in Course 1 were not appearing in-game, and there was no obvious reason for the bug.
key_stories.process: Kaze investigated the object's properties and behavior code. He traced the problem to a specific parameter (`bparam3`) and discovered its hidden function within the base engine.
key_stories.outcome: The issue was not a bug in Kaze's code but an obscure, intended feature of the original Mario 64 engine that he had accidentally triggered. The discovery provided a solution and a deeper understanding of the engine he's building upon.
key_stories.key_quote: There's a functionality in the Mario 64 engine where if you set the beep harm free to 255 the object does not spawn This is so fucking wild
